												PositiveEtherium is a nice-looking game with some innovative mechanics, considering  that it was not made by a big studio or with a big budget. Especially the idea of converting basebuilding into augmenting nodes on the map, which need to be captured, justifies some praise. Adding an alternative victory condition by letting you assault the enemies fleet in space and allowing to spare ressources to convert neutral armies are good ideas.NegativeEtherium is a Multiplayer-Title. You see your rank displayed on the main screen. I can not tell much about that. It might even be good. The problem is, that the game has barely any singleplayer. There is a campaign-like mode that lets you assault and conquer the AI on several planets, but it is basically just playing the same mission over and over with adjusted difficulty. It is basically the same structure, that "Emperor: Battle for Dune" had. Unfortunately, the campaign, althou having much more random events and tactical possibilities on the macro-map, has nothing to offer on the actual RTS level, which is the playing out of planetary combat. There is no story, there are no cutscenes, there is nothing but the unit descriptions and a short faction intro. The factions themselves also play rather indifferent for my taste, but that´s debatable. Result:If you are into Multiplayer RTS and seek for  some new twists on the genre for a good price, then this game is for you. If you are looking for an old-school campaign-RTS, I recommend you Grey Goo. (Which would be my decision.)4/10

												What do you get, when you have a multiplayer focused game, terrible marketing and therefore almost no awareness of your game, coupled with a low-budget approach? The answer is Etherium.The gameplay itself is solid and an experience, that focuses on the main things you'd expect from a strategy title:- rock/paper/scissors mechanics- multiple tech tiers- focus on map/ressource control- base building and defenseIt takes all of this and breaks it down to the bare essentials:- Counter mechanics are straith forward and most units are hardcounters to others. - Unit production is almost instant.- The map is controlled via sectors with a capture point in each. - Base buildings are limited to pre-defined locations in the sectors and can only be upgraded however you see fit (with the exception of defenses, which are limited by number in each sector). All that makes the game a very streamlined experience, which is not necessarily a bad thing. You can focus on making decision. And having only a limited set of options makes every choice count.So it doesn't sound to bad, right? HOWEVER as I initially stated Etherium is obviously built with Multiplayer in mind. You have only a lackluster "skirmish vs AI" - campaign mode, your "rank" is displayed in the main menu aswell as a button to enlist in matchmaking... If only pressing that button would do anything!Because YES, Etherium is dead already. I strongly advice to look it up on steamcharts.com, should you have any willingness to buy it left in you. With a peak of around 15 (!) players per day this is a multiplayer title with no one to play with. It should come as no suprise to the devs, that people will not pick up their game, if they fail so hard at raising awareness. Etherium is yet another failed attempt to create a low-budget title that stands on multiplayer alone, but just doesn't have the content, quality and appeal to get enough people to actually play it.Conclusion: Steer clear of this game and save yourself the money. Neither the Singleplayer nor Multiplayer are worth the price tag.

												Full Video Review - 


YouTube™ Video: Etherium Review 

			Views: 12,629		

			Cosmic reviews Etherium a real-time strategy game set in a science-fiction universe, developed by Tindalos Interactive and published by Focus Home Interactive.		

As you would expect this game is all about the ground combat. Etherium comes at a time where we have very few good real time strategy games around. The last one I played was mechs and mercs black talons which was a woefully bad game in every aspect. Rather than base building, Etherium core mechanic focuses around control points called monoliths. Instead of base building, one you have captured a monolith you can add extensions to it. These extensions have different functions such as a Etherium refinery for improved Etherium production in that zone, to a spaceport allowing you to deploy troops for that location.Each zone must be connected in some way to your main base to function properly. Should the enemy take a middle zone and split your territory. Buildings and more importantly Etherium production will go offline until reconnected. Speaking of Etherium, its the only production resource in the game and is aquiced every minute. Some regions will have Etherium spheres to harvest which are valuable zones to control and others won't.There are a variety of units available in each faction and more can be unlocked via the tech trees. Units each have strengths and weaknesses and through combat can be promoted in battle to become stronger. Etherium has a decent mix of infantry, tank and air units. My issue with them is that each factions is very similar in appearance to the next not just in aesthetic but in gameplay too. You also have turrets available to protect your bases but you are limited to three per region.One thing I love about the game is the indigenous sub factions on the planets. These sub factions can either be ignored, destroyed or even rallied to your cause in battle. By converting the necessary extension you build up points with a sub faction over time once the bar is full you gain control of these powerful ally's which can literally turn the tide of a battle. The enemy can also rally these sub factions to their side and it can often be a race to gain control of them.At the bottom of the screen you can see several abilities known as command skills. These skills are different for each faction and use up command points in battle which replenish over time. Command skills come in handy in a variety of situations, such as the orbital barrage which can be used to destroy units or buildings quickly.Another great feature of Etherium is the environmental hazards in battle known as climatic events. Depending on the type of planet your on you'll get a timed weather event that can have different effects. An example of this is a volcanic planet having eruptions that destroy units or electromagnetic storms that play havoc with your ability to use command skills. These events can hamper your battle plans but can also be used to your advantage.Battles are pretty fast paced which is something I like to see, it doesn't mean matches can't be long but it does mean than your kept on your toes often. I personally enjoyed that there is a variety of tactics to employ in battle and of course to ultimately win. I was also pretty impressed with the enemy AI as on the harder difficulties it was a serious challenge to compete.One to four player online multiplayer is available too which can be very fun. The fast paced nature of battles and with all the skills, environmental effects and sub factions in play, multiplayer can be a lot of fun. It certainly adds to the longevity of the title and I feel without the multiplayer component the game would not be worth the price tag.In all I feel that Etherium provides a good competent RTS experience. It's complete focus on macro-management rather than micro management leaves it feeling somewhat without the depth of other more renowned RTS games. It certainly has lots of room to improve, I think a larger conquest mode would have been better allowing for a longer campaign. Like I have mentioned I would have also liked to have seen more diversity between the factions units and play styles to give the game more replayability. However that being said, it is in my opinion one of the better RTS's to have been released in recent years.

Etherium ReviewDeveloped by Tindalos Interactive (known for Stellar Impact) and published by Focus Home Interactive (Cities XL Series, Trine 2, Farming Simulator), Etherium is a daring new multiplayer RTS game looking to pump fresh energy into a slumbersome genre. Not since Starcraft 2 has there been such a relevant sci-fi entry for a 4X multiplayer game. Tindalos is a small, independent studio so much credit is deserving for even attempting such a monumental task.In Etherium players will choose one of three different factions, each with their own unique abilities. These factions battle across multiple maps for control of a precious resource called etherium either against other players in multiplayer games or against AI players in single player skirmish mode and conquest mode. There are a multitude of units and upgrades available and units can level up through combat. Aside from the main factions, some maps also include a neutral faction which can advantageously be swayed into aiding your cause and be a nuisance for your opponents. The maps offer a variety of terrain features and can be used to your advantage as well. Additionally, Etherium contains a weather element based on terrain that can greatly impact battles and strategies.Etherium gameplay will be similar to most other RTS games of the genre and easy for veteran gamers to become familiar with early on (there is a tutorial included for newcomers), but in a much more direct approach. Instead of expansive base-building elements, Etherium introduces the idea of dividing the maps into zones with a central node where players can build a multi-functional "control structure" to gain control of that particular region. Each of these structures have a variety of upgrades and expansions available, offering a lot of flexibility in your strategic approach. This stream-lining concept allows for more focus on the combat element of the game while still offering a full compliment of benefits and options for your faction.While the graphics aren't going to leave players with that "Wow!" feeling, they are solid and more than get the job done. Zooming in will show some greater detail but is wasted since a game like this requires players to have a broader visibility of the map. There is a good soundtrack and the cut-scenes offer up a back story of sorts, which is good since (for unknown reasons) the developers chose not to include a lengthy single player campaign. The different factions are well-balanced, which is important for a mutiplayer combat game. This game has low system requirements and runs smoothly on most systems even using the highest visual settings. The AI is very intelligent and the combat is very direct so players can fully expect to be challenged even in single player skirmishes. The Good:=======+  Balanced and unique factions+  Variety of units, abilities, research improvements+  Challenging gameplay+  Various maps, terrains, weather elements+  Steam Trading Cards & Achievements+  Multiplayer Combat w/ Leaderboards+  Quality Graphics & Sound+  Smooth rotating camera with simple controls+  Comfortable UI+  Moderate replay valueThe Bad:======-  No single player campaign-  Combat units lack intelligence/must be controlled directly-  No combat formations or advanced control functions-  Graphics are dull & un-interestingFinal Thoughts:===========While Etherium doesn't reach its full potential and may fall short in comparison with some of the most renown 4X Space RTS games of our generation, it is still a solid game and offers many hours of entertaining gameplay. Everything this game does, it does well and could be the building block for a successful series with a few tweaks and additional improvements. Time will tell, but for RTS fans who have been neglected by the genre for a long time, this game is one you definitely want to get your hands on. Etherium is not the scifi RTS game you are looking for.  The game has some really interesting concepts, but overwhelmingly fails to provide a rewarding experience.At $30 the game simply doesn't pack enough content to be worth the time.  An average RTS game is going to be worth hundreds of hours of gameplay, this one might not pass the 20 hour marker.Balance in the game is pretty awful with one faction just being overwhelmingly better than the others.What the game does offer is a unique take on base building giving you a lighter version of it.  Your home base can build a number of attachments.  Logistics allows you to build more units, tech allow you to build better units, and refineries allow you to earn more money.  Then there are more specialized buildings that can be used as part ofa strategy, like the military industrial complex which reduces costs from losing units.On the map are various points that need to be captured.  Each point will build 1 or 3 attachments.  Building with only 1 attachment can build a refinery.  Ones with 3 cannot.The main problem of the game is that things sort of snowball out of control fast.  Holding on to an extra base gives you a definitive advantage over your opponent in which case it's less likely you'll be able to come back from a loss.The game also features the option of buying out neutral factions.  Neutral factions will only attack you if you attack them and are place in areas that would eliminate a potential flank.  Buying out factions is a huge investment and honestly... a waste of time.  The advantage is gaining a few extra units that don't count towards your unit cap.It's a very disappointing game in a poorly planned series.  Hold off on buying this one indefinitely.

												Etherium plays like a slower paced RTS-lite with a focus on resource management and control in conjunction with unit management. There are three interesting and visually varied races with their own uses of the resource, and the units, structures, assets and graphics in general are pleasant to look at, but combat is mediocre, gameplay is bland and gets very boring very fast and when considering the frequent crashes and problems, this might well be worth completely passing by. I feel like the developers have tried to emphasize the battlefield as a whole and the player choices and routes to different areas, and have tried to strip the standard building/production mechanics down to a minimum so that the players' focus is more general and overviewish like in, for example, Supreme Commander, but it hasn't worked very well and honestly results in the game feeling bland as a whole.There is no focus on single-player other than a very lacklustre vs A.I. Skirmish series which doesn't offer any story or anything you'd expect from the big players like the Age of Empires', the Starcrafts, etc. I understand that it's a smaller title with a lower budget, but the lack of single-player element really is a big turn off.So then the focus is on the multiplayer, which has its own problems. All there is to let you know how you're doing overall is a rank in the top left, and with no stats or information on your matches or even your games as a whole, it's basically a matter of finding and playing games for their own sake, which sounds fine in theory, but in reality is another bland, boring aspect of this game.That's not even mentioning the fact that multiplayer is essentially dead. It took me 12+ minutes to find a game, during the free trial no less, and there was no alert or notification that I'd joined a game, but that didn't matter because my opponent was apparently afk anyway. For a game focused entirely on multiplayer to have so few players and nothing to encourage team-building, tournaments or improvement is simply an appalling failure.HighlightsThe visual styling and art styles of each of the three races are mildly interesting and generally pretty good. The maps are all fairly varied and the map assets are interesting. In general, all the visual elements are fairly good in Etherium.Node management is very smooth and quick. The ability to replace or move a Spaceport across the map for example, takes just two clicks and 2 seconds.* Despite the games many design issues, the gameplay as a whole can be fairly fun when against evenly matched opponents.* The different routes to victory are interesting and add a little depth that could've otherwise been missed.MistakesThe main problem with Etherium, at least at the time of review, is technical. Unexplained and seemingly random crashes are very frequent and even completing the tutorial for me involved 3 crashes and re-openings of the game. With no patch notes from the developers this is simply unforgivable and means buying this game is a risk. Though there are user suggested fixes in community posts. There are also a number of smaller problems that bring this title down.* Units are very basic, and provide hard counters to other units. There is no real depth of combat strategy, it's more about area and resource management, which is fine, but something more than rock/paper/scissors would've been appreciated.* The U.I. is very unintuitive at first, and takes too long to figure out, and the tutorial, while polished, does a poor job of keeping things simple, especially when continually crashing.RecommendationsI've given this a fairly hard time, but at the end of the day the game would actually be an average to above average RTS title if the Multiplayer existed. Unfortunately the genre has far better options at better prices, and for £14.99/19.99€/$19.99 at the time of review, it's just not worth it unless you're an RTS fiend. Had the multiplayer been a success, this would've been a fair choice and average+ game but for now, there are better options on Steam and elsewhere and you're better served passing this by.* Looking for somewhat similar but more solid RTSs' on Steam? Supreme Commander Gold Edition is equally priced, has far more content and does the world overview feel much better. Supreme Commander 2 is also worth checking and is cheaper and more highly rated. Grey Goo also focuses on decision making and resource management but has much stronger story and single-player, but it's twice the price of Etherium.* A seemingly successful fix to the after-game crashes has been posted on the Community

But...--------------------------Updated 31.03: Soloplayer Campaign Review:There are three "campaigns" for each faction. After you've chosen your faction, you'll get introduced by some pictures and voiceover/text to the motives and backgrounds of them, which is interesting, though it could be implemented better (cinematics would upgrade this alot). Then a little tutorial and the thing starts. You can imagine this as sort of a round based board game, with 6 planets. Each round, you can make your moves with the fleet, upgrade your techlevel based on the techpoints you hold. Per round you have general action points and fleet specific actionpoints.  With the general action points you can buy cards (you get a card each round), play a card/cards, spy the techlevel and missions of your opponent, or - if you can - buy a new fleetWith the fleet action points, you can shoot the enemy fleet which is in the same orbit, repair your hull, conquer/attack a sector of a planet. Goal of the game is to hold at least 12 winningpoints for one round, or - I'm guessing now - to hold the most points by the end of the last round (I think it was like 16 rounds). You get those points by completing missions and play the cards giving you those points. Resumee: I really like this gamemode. It will be a different game everytime you play it, especially with the tough KI it won't bore you too much. Though the fights are always the standart fights. 												Cute.I'd say it is 60%-80% strategy, 40%-20% tactics.Even the tactics portion of the game (the RTS part where on-planet units battle) has some strategic overtones.See, there are two parts to this game, the "space" part (turn based), and the on-planet part (real-time). You start out in space, build your space fleet in your home planet, and you invade planets with it, sending down invasion forces down on planets. Your fleets can battle other fleets in space, and your on-planet base can be upgraded to be able to attack the enemy fleet in space. There are two paths to victory: Either destroy the enemy on-planet (their main base) or send their fleet packing, abandoning its forces on-planet.Graphics are not too heavy. 												2/5 in theory, 0/5 in practice.  Dear god the crashes!  I can even replicate them at will.  Steam really lowered the bar on aplha.... WHAT? IT'S BEEN FULLY OUT SINCE MARCH?  I guess they decided to skip all the testing and QA phases.Read below or pretty much any of the other reviews that aren't obvious shills and you'll see.  With bugs like these this game should be considered a Beta right now at best, and it doesn't look like the dev's are still working on it.STEAM, PLEASE PULL THIS GAME UNTIL IT IS NOT BROKEN.When the game works, it plays a lot like Empire At War and has command weapons ala Red Alert 3.  The bots are smart and the board-game style galaxy conquest, although not unique, adds some replayability.  There is no actual campaign other than the galactic conquest.Multiplayer has no public matches option (either that or shows no matches by default and you can't search for "").If the game worked and had real multiplayer and a campaign it could be a really polished title.  However, even getting passed the crashes, the game is a mess.  Here's a few reasons why: - AI goes from retard to genius between Easy and Medium. - Badly designed load screens (press to continue after match loads will press itself after a few seconds) - Unbalanced species - Bulky and poorly laid out UI (keyboard shortcuts suck by default too)- Important messages disappear quickly and/or get replaced by useless information (like letting you know your division is under attack during this firefight that's been going on for the last 5 minutes rather than the volcano is about to erupt) - No save game option during matches (so, when it crashes at the end of a match, which it will, you have to start that part of the conquest over again)Overall there isn't really anything unique about the gameplay itself.  Between command and conquer, starcraft, empire at war and supreme commander, it's all been done before and better.  The only originality I see is in the galactic conquest - kind of like the EAW version only with trading cards and no space battles.  If you see me playing this in the next 3 days (free), it's because I want to finish ONE conquest before I uninstall it forever (right now certain territories crash after I beat them so it's a mini-game in itself.)DO NOT SPEND MONEY ON THIS. - INSTALL FOR THE FREE WEEK ONLY IF YOU WANT TO BE FRUSTRATED

												Every once in a while, from time to time, you find something awesome among the tens of titles produced by small studios, Etherium is one of those games and the more you play it the more you will enjoy it.The game (developed by Tindalos studios and published by Focus Home Interactive) tries a few things which most game companies would avoid in these times of fantasy themed MOBAs, namely to create a hardcore-scifi RTS game, from the very first look you know the developers took heavy inspiration in the likes of Supreme Commander, Starship Troopers, Aliens and other classics of scifi, no Warhammer 40,000 though, there are no chainsword melee oriented units neither blatant "magic" psychic powers although there is a considerable reliance on Clarke's Third Law.from a gameplay perspective you will find a very interesting mix of concept which includes territory control, squads and hard-counters, all of this is quite well balanced as no faction really is overpowered, a lot of this is helped by the fact there are many mirror units, but worry not you will still have enough variety as every faction has special powers which make them unique and show a wider array of possible tactics. For instance, you can use the human Consortium financial support to boost your resources in order to get an economic edge over your enemies, the intari on the other hand can automatically level up their units from some command points, allowing for greater shooting accuracy in the battlefield, the Vectides on the other hand have deployable healing and evasion fields, which allow their troops to stay longer.Some other options will make you choice different tactics to defeat the enemy, should you tech rush your awesome heavy walkers while holding the line or should you try to break the enemy's early economy through raiding units? Shall you go for a full military assault or turtle while your orbital cannons force your enemy to evacuate his fleet? Take also in consideration the special events of the maps, which depending on the planet may come from volcanic eruptions which cut certain map sections to hurricanes which may destroy everyone's airforces.The implementation of subfactions also brings other possibilities, you may get these powerful forces through the sacrifice of certain kind of incomes such as command, tech or etherium points, indeed, you may also just wipe them out to capture their territories for further resources and experience.From a background and visual point Etherium brings three unique factions which have been invited by a mysterious entity known as the Smuggler to fight for this precious resource:The human Consortium, kinda like your OCP/Futuretech/Clonglom-O/Weyland-Yutani/Atlas on steroids, through economic power and illegal actions they have become most powerful human power in the universe, eclipsing the old nations of Earth, they relay on monetary and construction tactics and bring an army with the high-tech blocky look you are used whenever someone portrays humany in the coming centuries, no utopia for mankind here, but you still have a solid Starcraft Terran looking arsenal.The Awakened of Intar are your cool scary dogmatic aliens, older than mankind, focused on battle and tactical prowess, with a marble and crystalline stylized look which speaks of a fanatic and spiritual drive, this is perhaps the most "magical" faction, with a bit of protoss and another bit of eldar in the mix (without going as far as psionic blades or psychic swords), they use teleporting and time predicting capabilities as well as levelling up powers, great for wreaking havoc across the battlefield.Finally the Vectide Empire is the bio-chemical looking faction, with insectoid looking units, lots of glowing green stuff and the classic martian vibe, they may also remind you of the Hierarchy from Universe At War, long story short, these guys managed to transfer their consciousness into etherium, so if you are thinking about the necrons yes, there seems to be a bit of influence on them, and also the daleks for good measure, take advantage of their healing and evasion drones as well as their infantry boosting structures to overwhelm the enemy through sheer resilience.In the audio department the game makes a decent job with the sound effects and the voice, although it's a bit sad all units have the same stock phrases at least they may remain solid. The music is okm even nice to bring the scifi atmosphere, just' don't expect anything like what you get whenever Frank Klepacki is around.In conclussion, for 30 bucks you get an awesome game, if you have any chance try to get it as soon as possible, you will not regret it.

Verdict: check back again if the devs ever decide to finish this properly. This feels like an incomplete and still very unstable Early Access title.What it has in its favour: I absolutely love RTS games. That in itself could practically outweigh almost anything. AI is decently intelligent in its decisions (seeks you out, attacks weak points, retreats indefensible/dying units, aware of the environment). UI looks good and is functional. Graphics are good.What it has against it: No single player campaign. A big negative. You only get the equivalent of a skirmish/quickmatch setup screen against the AI, and basically all you can do is try the different maps. Multi-player option suffers from very small player base, even on a free weekend event. The AI at the moment does not have much of a defense against a rush right at the start. All that intelligence wasted cause it never gets past being bombed to pieces right away. Several of the side and float panels can be very obtrusive and tend to get in the way of big parts of the battlefield. Gets very annoying very quickly. The default keyboard hotkey controls are a mess. SQZD instead of WASD to move around?? Randomly chosen letters for 'Skill 1' to 'Skill 6', instead of 1-6, NumPad or F keys. They can be redefined, but for some reason sometimes they reset back to the wacky default. HUGE NEGATIVE: unstable as all hell. First couple of starts didn't even get me into the menu. Then just trying to change the graphics settings to use my native resolution (nothing exotic, 1920x1200) crashed it again. Several attempts at running the tutorial had it just get stuck right after the mission intro cinematic, with no error whatsoever, but completely nonreactive to anything other than Alt-F4. Changing to a smaller windowed mode finally got me into the tutorial, only to have that crash in the end too, which persisted with every skirmish match I tried.There are a couple of nitwits on the forum going around blaming the crashes on people having crap systems or old drivers. Don't let that deceive you: the game does not even come close to straining my rig, during the moments it does run. The fault is in the game (or engine) coding, period.Judging from all this, this title should not have left Early Access yet. This is neither complete nor stable. A game with potential but let down severely by releasing it in this state, and unless it gets some major additional development, patching, and (single-player) content, not worth the current price-tag even at 50%. Devs: please debug and complete this game.

												Fine, I recognisethe small budget outfit and the indie title. That aside, the game still remains buggy, crashing for me after each mission. So minus major points there. Graphics-wise, I'd be impressed if this was the early 2000s, but I wouldn't complain so much. Graphics in games, well, the units in the game collectively act as a squadron, which means each unit has to be animated, and controlled, while reinforcements do come in to replenish fallen squadmates.That mechanic, quickly gets boring and, since reinforcing fallen squadmates don't take resources, it's easy to defend, tough to attack. So what's it like? Well, Etherium is kinda like leading campaigns on a world map (galaxy map), targetting specific planets to gain territory. Unfortunately, I've only played less than 2 hours, and I fail to see the appeal here, as more planets should automatically mean more resources to bring to war but to avoid unbalanced the developer didn't put too much into it. Once you've selected a territory to attack, it enters this real-time strategy mode, where its the basic gather resources and pump units and attack. However, the battlemap is divided into areas where you control via building outposts, sort of like the WarCraft III ziggurats of the Undead, where you just expand your territory, while the enemy expands his.On the early onset, there's some early skirmishes, where the faster units start harassing certain locations of base. However, after a while, it drags on into this sort of trench warfare with the AI, which sends units forth, your defense leave them running, and they go back to their outpost which heals and reinforces the squads, and rinse, dry and repeat. Victory comes either by quickly overruning the opponent and sapping his resources in the early game, pulling out a technologically superior unit or taking control of one of the various neutral spawns on the map. I find myself overrunning the opponent with a mix of heavy tanks, and long range mortars. However, because of the "tech tree"is in the larger world map, instead of the ingame battle map, you gotta choose which tech tree to upgrade in your war against the opponent. Fine, this means that if you got rocket infantry, while the opponent chooses to upgrade only his air units, you got him beat and overrun, and it would take many turns before he will have sufficient tech points to muster a counter. This would make for some painful games. Learning curve is steep, the game has too many mechanics to overcompensate for its lack of tactical debt, and one of my biggest annoyance is the unit voices. Storyline is uninteresting, and only meh. 4/10 4/10 with rice.

												as gameplay goes, I can best describe this as "RTS for Newbies" as it takes a semi streamlined style of RTS base building akin to Company of Heroes or Dawn of War 2. Not an amazing game, but it was easy enough for me to pick up and play. Though I must say it does feel a bit incomplete at times and the tutorial leaves much to be desired and the HUD is a bit chaotic and hard to follow. Once you get into it though it gets a little better, but it still leaves much to be desired.Do I recommend this game? yeah i think it's worth a play if you like Dawn of War 2 and COH. The gameplay might get old rather quickly, but I still stand by what i say. It's fun to kill time with. You have 3 factions each with their own special units and their own special off-map abilities with different types of economies and population growth. For example one factoin starts off with 4 "Division" (unit) slots and a special unit that specializes in tactical espianage while another faction starts off with 3 "Division" slots, requires a research level 3 to access their Special Elite units but in the mean time has an off-map support that allows a player to rabidly promote basic units to higher, more effective levels so as to outclass enemies in the battlefield. The three factions are easy to learn but difficult to master and and you can choose 1 of 4 different maps from up to 6 different environments, each with their own unique environmental hazards that can make or break unit deployments. during key points in your skirmish. So yeah, I can recommend this game for the price that it is now ($20.00). It's not the best RTS I've ever played but it's more certainly not the worst. Some good effort was put into making this game and it shows.

Posted: July 14, 2015
												It tries to do too much. The outpost system, limiting units, limiting structures and a dumbed down way to upgrade your tech level (ways to unlock more powerful units/turrets) just dont mesh well here. Add to it the minor factions that may or may not be on your map, and its a game that tries too much, and fails.With limited access to units, you are left with either expanding rapidly, or build turrets to attempt to slowly turtle forward to new outposts. However both methods have major disadvantages.-Expanding rapidly leads to issues with making the ideal unit comp. With so few units possible to command at one time, you either have to guess at what you will be fighting or move forward with a very generalised comp. -Crawling foward has the issue of being low on resorces. Since you need to expand to increase income, slowly moving forward leads to being potentially left behind in tech level and unit production. That is an issue because of the limit on turrets per outpost (territory under you control). With only three turrets to defend with, you must (again) guess at what is going to be thrown at you, or generalise. Ultimatly, the game has interesting ideas but is crippled by the extreemly limiting population caps. Going forth and hoping that your comp will be relivant when you enter combat is never fun. Add to it the limited locations that you can call units from (you CAN get them to your front line faster, but that has major drawbacks depending on where the front line is), and sending in your few precious units to get instantly destroyed can become extreemly costly.

												In light of the failures of the Command and Conquer series to produce anything resembling C&C: Tiberium Sun to C&C2: Yuri's Revenge in the recent years, it only makes sense that a company push into the RTS business to try and pick up a broken market.Etherium isn't that push-company.Mind you, I only played through the tutorial before the game crashed, so that's all this review goes off of before I uninstalled the game. If I can't play through a tutorial before it smokes itself, then I can't be bothered to play it with more than a hundred games in my Steam Library. #PCMasterRaceThe graphics are gorgeous. The scaling in and out is perfect and works well with the resolutions, and I picked a medium-sized 2058x1128 or something with Maximum-everything. #LoveMyR9290XThe gameplay is a bit clunky and slow-paced, from what I managed in the tutorial after it ends and allows you to finish the level out. Building troops is meh and there's little instruction in the tutorial on the slots per command post (some have 1 and some have 3), however its your call once you discover that a slot can be filled with tech, repair, more troops, etc ... but these aren't covered in the tutorial.The vagueness of the tutorial is also irritating. There's no indication that once air transport has lifted comms troops, and you move them, of how to drop them. So you're looking all over the map, re-reading the directions of what to do next and eventually you'll find the drop-circle over the air transport. Seems obvious, but there's 1000000000 buttons on the HUD for every little thing and you're clueless as to what everything does in the beginning.Suggestion: Grey them out for the Tutorial until they're usable. A bit overwhelming.And in the end, I got Raiders to join me, picked up some little rocket buggies, orbital struck the enemy base for ... 0 damage, pretty much, like the tanks, a bit depressing when it comes to tactical firepower and then you just overwhelm the base with like 30 troops and the game crashes.</the end>My windows manager showed that the game was taking something like 2M K of memory at the time of crash (on 8 cores with 16 GB of RAM isn't much, but I digress) and tried to freeze up my system.Not sure why. Nothing is out of date. No explanations. And in reading the forums or community board, only morons claiming that "your PC is a potato" is the answer for crashes and you have bad drivers. To him I say, "Blow me, trollfays. Your nubile PC is no match or comparison for my Kingslayer. Uninstall." ... or something nerdy like that.Stick to old C&C if you need your RTS-cravings satiated.

												Have you played an RTS within the past 10 years? Then you probably have seen everything worth seeing in Etherium already. The biggest issue with RTS games nowadays (and other "dead genres" being "revived" lately) is that they try to get away with being just "good enough". There is nothing groundbreaking, nothing creative or inventive, no new game design ideas present here and, despite having its release pushed back multiple times, feels like instant bargain bin fodder during a genre drought. Outside of the mandatory multiplayer, you have a campaign with convoluted rules (with each side having their own secondary victory conditions) and a skirmish mode. The campaign is very frustrating because of simple oversights, like not being able to save during your opponent's turns and a star system UI that doesn't provide enough information. I spent easily almost two hours defending my territories during opponent's turns simply because quitting the game meant restarting the opponent's turn. This is of course on top of all the issues present in the actual gameplay......of which there is little to mention. The main objective (and single game mode) is to either destroy the other player's main base or deplete their tickets by bombarding their mothership with turrets high in the tech tree. Regions of territory are strictly defined and can have only one base inside for adding upgrades onto. The problem with the territories having a fixed size is that smaller territories only allow smaller bases. This creates claustrophobic maps, with clearly defined chokepoints that force you down a corridor to your opponent's base. Most of my campaign victories were from converting the neutral factions on the map and attack-moving them into the enemy's main base. The absolute bare minimum went into Etherium's factions and their unit design. Units for each race have creative names like Standard Infantry, Siege Vehicle, and Bomber. Races share all the same units (!) with each having only 4 unique units. This might be acceptable in a turn-based strategy game where you have 20+ factions or dozens of units, but here you only have about 6 different units for each unit type. Each race also shares 3 of their 6 faction skills, similar to Dawn of War's faction ability system. Everything about the races just feels very cut-and-pasted and bland and makes me wonder why this game's release was pushed back multiple times.I am ashamed to have fallen for the hype for this game. If you are thirsty for a good (or great or amazing, whatever) RTS, then revisit an old one instead of wasting money on this. This game couldn't be any blander or generic if it tried. If a monkey hitting keys at random on a typewriter could eventually type out the complete works of William Shakespeare, then this game is proof that they can code a video game too.

												Etherium is a little title with big problems. It is mainly a little title, because for the price asked, 29.99$ on launch, it simply doesn’t pack enough content to be worth the hassle. Outdated graphics, lazily-created assets and the lack of innovation bring this title down to the rank of a mere husk of what similar titles in a similar price range can offer. Etherium does actually sport some innovative concepts, such as differentiating between macro management of a full-scale interplanetary invasion with some table-top gaming features and singular battles or dynamic weather changes across the maps which require players to adapt in order to survive, but these are executed so blatantly that any sign of innovation gets lost in a sea of repetitiveness, and in the general lack of originality this title seems to ooze. Were players able to look past the lack of lore, the unoriginal factions and gameplay, they would be stuck with a brain-dead AI, which will do stupid things such as walking their units straight into an orbital bombardment or a volcanic eruption, randomly stop playing by simply amassing resources without creating any units or, especially on Easy difficulty, stubbornly try to do the same thing over and over again expecting things to change, while retaining the ability to become a great challenge if set to the hardest difficulty possible. All of this makes Etherium, in its current state, a game that should not be bought. If looking for an RTS experience, players would be better off buying similar but more fleshed out titles or, in any case, direct their attention elsewhere.Read the full review here: http://www.gamerheadlines.com/reviews/etherium/

I'm not a Chicken!It must suck to be a chicken, you lay eggs and people eat them, you don't lay enough eggs and people eat you.It's little wonder that chickens have a nervous disposition, If I were a chicken, I'd be a chicken too.Avoiding the EggcupThere are plenty of other less tasty creatures that lay eggs, most of which have some sort of strategy to keep them safe until they hatch.Turtles will bury their eggs in the sand, penguins will shuffle about with their eggs balancing on their feet (Happy Feet was a great film wasn't it!) and Xenomorphs will lay their eggs in the chests of Colonial Marines.Inter-dimensional ChickensNow there's another creature, the Madrith (some sort of giant inter-dimensional chicken), which has a unique strategy to keep its eggs safe, it lays them in another dimension where I assume it hopes that they'll be safe from their natural predators.Unfortunately this strategy doesn't really work out too well for the Madrith as the dimension it has chosen to be its safety blanket is ours.What came first, The Madrith or the Egg?Well, from our perspective, that's an easy one. The egg, it's always the egg, there's a perfectly good planet floating around minding its own business when "Boom" a ruddy great egg appears on its surface, no sign of the Madrith, just the egg, it's always just the tasty, tasty egg.Egg and SoldiersThese particular giant eggs are far too valuable to be left alone whilst nature takes its course,  they're so valuable in fact, that when they start appearing once every thousand years or so, the whole galaxy gears up to fight over them.Free Range Spicy Tiberium AlternativeYou see, these eggs contain a unique and amazing resource, a minute quantity of which can produce enough energy to power a large colony and enable vast vessels to travel through space at the speed of light.This eggy gas is so valuable that the three dominant races of the galaxy, in anticipation of a visit from the extra-dimensional Easter bunny, build up their forces and the millennial "Egg Wars" begin. Eggs-ploreLuckily for us, the  Madrith are creatures of habit, they always lay their eggs on six "deposit" planets, each with their own varied environments, ranging from" Hoth-like" Ice Worlds to "Tatooine-like" desert globes, each environment provides its own challenges, it's own weather events (which is a nice touch) and each will require a different strategic approach.To get to these planets you're going to need to construct fleets and park them in orbit, from there you can clear out any enemy fleets before sending the troops down for the ground warDon't expect a "Distant Worlds" or "Sins of a Solar Empire" type experience here though, this is a simplistic "space layer" used primarily to select which planet to fight on next with a little espionage and research mixed in for good measure.Eggs-ploitWhen you've selected your battleground of choice, you'll be treated  to a cut scene showing the seed of your first colony drop down from space and establish your initial base.You'll quickly want to sniff out some eggy goodness and start gathering its Etherium, this will be the resource you'll be using to build units and structures in the game.Eggs-pandEach planet is divided up into territories with each territory having a monolith which you need to take control of.This is achieved by building a "Comms Infantry" which you can send out to establish an outpost at the monolith site.These outposts can then be expanded with a choice of extensions, each of which will provide a bonus regarding Etherium production, research, number of units you can control, etc.You can also build a limited number of turrets to help defend your interests in each territory. There are a few different types to choose from, each with their own particular strengths and weaknesses.Eggs-terminateThey say that attack is the best form of defence and that certainly holds true in Etherium.You're going to need an effective war machine to remove any unwanted intruders from the map and there are plenty of units for you to construct, providing you've had chance to research them, the command points to control them and the Etherium to pay for their construction.This research mechanic does  make the initial combat encounters of the game a slightly shallow affair as you'll only be churning out basic infantry until you've managed to build up a few research points to unlock the more interesting units.Egg-straIn addition to the three dominant powers in the game you also encounter three minor races.You can steam roller over these and wipe them out or if you want to be a little more subtle, you can try and bring them round to your side, this is achieved by converting some of your Etherium refinery improvements in to a black-market service which will gain the minor factions favour, you might even benefit from a unique unit or two if you take the time to play nice with the little guys.There are also a bunch of special abilities you can utilise to give you an edge on the battlefield, these range from temporarily dispelling the fog of war in a certain place on the map to blasting the hell out of an area with an orbital cannon (which is hugely satisfying!).There is also a political card mechanic which you can play in the space layer of the game between battles, these could help you ally with one of the previously mentioned "little races" or maybe even force an enemy to miss a turn. This is a welcome addition to add a little more depth to the game.FabergeLike a Faberge egg, Etherium can be quite pleasing to look at initially, holding the right mouse button down lets you look around the landscape, you can even look up to the sky where you'll see ships in orbit taking pot shots at each other.However, the more you look  at a Faberge Egg, the more you realise it's just a glittery egg, the same can be said of Etheriums graphics, once the novelty of the right click free cam wears off, the graphics themselves begin to look a little mundane, not awful, just not as special as you'd initially hoped."Cut" ScenesDon't go into this game expecting rich cut scenes and a detailed narrative thread interwoven between the battles or you'll be disappointed, the fight for the eggs premise is about as deep as the plot gets, which is a little disappointing, I've always viewed little narrative cut scenes in RTS titles to be a reward for winning the preceding battle.Hello, Anyone There?Etherium also really wants to be a multiplayer title, which is fine and probably explains the lack of narrative, but online play does seem a little on the quiet side, especially for such a new game, that's not to say that by the time you read this a healthy community won't have built up around the multiplayer experience....  I hope so because it's needed to increase the longevity of the games appeal.However, the single player campaign and skirmish modes whilst not dazzling  are perfectly entertaining in their own right and the AI seems competent which is always a huge plus for an RTS title.Egg-eriumEtherium is a competent RTS and it ticks a lot of the right boxes, if your looking for a straight forward no nonsense experience you could do a lot worse, the downside is that whilst its a perfectly playable RTS it doesn't really bring anything new to the breakfast table.It's like an egg, it's nice, you know what to expect, if you're in the mood for it then you'll probably enjoy it, but sometimes you want something more than an egg for breakfast.For the full review and others please take the time to visit http://www.review-well.com/

												I gave this a try during the free trial they had a while ago, and after stewing over the experience for a while, I can safely declare that I will not be buying it. I'm starved for a good RTS. Strategy games like that are an old love, and that's why I gave this a try. It has potential, but it just doesn't tick the right boxes for me.First of all, the tutorial is extremely constrictive. It refuses to let you do anything but what they want you to do. This means that anything but basic controls has to be learned in the game proper.Although there is a skirmish mode, it's only part of the game. The conquest mode is a series of skirmishes, where instead of one victory, you'll have a series of several, where wins and losses will determine your abilities for the major part of the game, and where I spent my time.Right now, I can say that it's broken. The controls in Conquest Mode are unituitive, and I've spent at least two minutes trying to control one of my battle fleets. Fleets at the southern end of the galaxy risk being "out of bounds", which is my way of saying impossible to select. It didn't cost me the game, but it cost me a few minutes of game time.Victory in the game is determined either by being the first to maintain 12 victory points, or by having the most victory points at the end. How to gain victory points is mostly randomized, but holding territories for extended time is a guarantee. Outside of that, holding specific territories, successfully destroying enemy fleets or palaces, or simply playing the right card will gain you a foothold.And the cards are something that I like the theory of, but have one fatal flaw. They're supposed to provide tactical advantages, like speeding the development of a planet, or letting a fleet move again. All I ended up with were cards that reduced all player relations towards the rogues. Haven't the foggiest idea what that's supposed to be, but they just sat there, preventing me from getting a card that could have won the game.Conquest Mode also determines what technologies you can use. At first, you're very limited in what you can deploy in a skirmish. But, as the turns go by, you can spend technology points on techs, which you then deploy in skirmishes. To keep this in check, you can't deploy them all on the first turn. You need an equal number of technology stations installed in your bases in order to call in or construct something of a specific technology era.And finally, the skirmishes themselves. It's very unforgiving. All you have is Etherium, a currency that you use to buy reinforcements from your own faction (rather rude). Controlling more territories means more Etherium, and more stations to increase either the number of units you can deploy, the tech level you can use, or special commands to your fleet, such as orbital bombardment. Generally, someone who grabs territory early has the upper hand, just deploy turrets wherever they're needed. Although having a tech that the enemy just can't counter is a help (using Bombers when they enemy has no AA units, for example) in the end the fastest land grab will win.Skirmish Mode also lacks a pause button, so you spend a lot of time flicking between your landing bays and the front line. If I want to reinforce a battle with, say, a mortar infantry unit, I have to go to my nearest airport, purchase the infantry, wait several seconds for them to arrive, and then assign them to an airship, wait several more seconds, and then order them to the battle, and finally air drop them into the battle. All this is time that I need to spend keeping an eye on the current battle, because at any moment, the enemy could start construction on a turret, call in an orbital bombardment, or sound a retreat that I want to fire my own bombardment on. Either allow me to queue up orders, or give me a pause button.This is mostly just a massive rant, because there's something about this game that just brings out the worst in me. It isn't an RTS like I'm used to, and although it has potential, it certainly isn't something that I'm interested in paying for.

												The only major issue i have with the game is that there is no Auto-resolve option in the single player Conquest mode. While this isn't a huge issue it does make the game feel rather long. Each fleet has two actions per turn. This means that in single player Conquest you can end up fighting two battles per alien turn because they seem to enjoy attacking you over the other faction. When you start getting to the point they have two or even three fleets in orbit of one of your worlds and each fleet can attack twice thats a LOT of battles to fight without an auto-resolve and since most battles take 30-40 minutes for me... Its a good game and i enjoy but please for the love of god add in a auto-resolve :)

												Ok so I am pretty wound up about this game.   The way you create units that can only be dropped at your base point might not be a problem if you didn't have to be at your base telling it specifically were to drop the units rather than setting a waypoint or points that created units get delivered to which means you can never concentrate on your battles.  By the end of the maps your base is far from the final battles that you just spend time mini map jumping.  The idea of nodes on the bases is a promising one but it never really delivers much.  I know this is not made by a big studio and it is pretty cheap to buy but if all it does is frustrate then I would say save up for Deserts of Kharak, Grey Goo or Ashes of the Singularity all of which are far superior RTS games.

												It's pretty obvious that this game has a negative conotation. I don't support the developers abandoning the game but their recent titles are pretty good. If you're one of the lucky ones like me who can get past the constant crashing, you'll find that the gameplay isn't spectacular, and neither are the graphics. The grand strategy is very interesting and very well done, but the constant land conquest will eventually get any player to wish they were playing another game. Ultimately, this game is like No Man's Sky. It could've been so much more but ended up falling short.
